answers.a: Ethyl maltol (E637) is a flavor enhancer that adds a sweet, caramel-like note to foods and beverages. It is permitted in many regions at low concentrations and is structurally related to maltol.
It’s very potent; in foods it’s typically used at tens of ppm (about 0.001–0.01%), and JECFA’s acceptable daily intake is 0–2 mg/kg body weight per day.
Use only tiny amounts; many formulators add about 0.25–1% of a 10% ethyl maltol-in-propylene glycol solution (roughly 0.025–0.1% EM, or ~250–1000 ppm), as higher levels can mute flavors.

answers.q: ejuice how to use ethyl maltol
answers.a: Dissolve it in propylene glycol to make ~10% solution, then add sparingly to the flavor base and adjust after steeping; start very low because too much can flatten flavors.
A synthetic flavor enhancer (E637) that provides sweet, caramelized “cotton candy” notes and boosts perceived sweetness; it’s an approved flavoring substance used at very low levels.

answers.q: how much ethyl maltol in e liquid
answers.a: Typically 0.025–0.1% ethyl maltol by weight (e.g., 0.25–1% of a 10% solution) is enough for e-liquids; exceeding this often mutes or overly candies the mix.
